ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was a really wonderful course. I learned about Northern complicity with slavery, and about how the Ivy League universities were established with the profits from and labor of enslaved Africans, and the stolen land of indigenous Americans. I also learned about how to do archival research and develop a historical argument.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated the opportunity to contribute to the research of the Yale and Slavery Project. I find it exciting that student research will contribute to this effort to reckon with Yale's history with slavery and hopefully motivate reparations.
I think the books assigned and visits to Beinecke were extremely helpful, as well as the walking your of the city. I think they gave me great reference for how to do things/ look at things on my own.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I don't know if this course will be offered again, but Professor Feimster, Professor Rugemer, and Teanu Reid are all wonderful instructors and I would recommend a course with them.
I would, but I would caution you to not overload your schedule along with this class.
